entry.title: [FilesBulkPinning] Only show the cloud icon when bulk pinning progresses
entry.content:
The cloud icon shows progress as bulk pinning slowly pins and downloads

a users corpus. If the bulk pinning progress fails via either not

having sufficient disk space or the device going offline, the cloud icon

should still be visible to show this state. For all other states (i.e.

any fatal errors or the preference being disabled) the cloud icon should

be hidden.

entry.title: Split OnFailedRequestInternal() and BeginNavigationImpl() into helper functions.
entry.content:
GetFrameHostForNavigation() can potentially fail, if a speculative

RenderFrameHost that already exists is still waiting for a navigation

commit to be acknowledged. Splitting these functions apart and moving

the logic to select a RenderFrameHost to a new helper function makes it

easier to post a closure to resume the navigation when the speculative

RenderFrameHost commits later.



For BeginNavigationImpl(), the same-document navigation path now asserts

that there is always a site for the SiteInstance: otherwise, the

navigation shouldn't be a same-document navigation.



Bug: 1220337

entry.title: [BRP/clang-plugin] emit error for raw_ptr/raw_ref pointing to a `STACK_ALLOCATED()` object
entry.content:
- Add an option `check-raw-ptr-to-stack-allocated` to the clang plugin

- When specified, `raw_ptr` or `raw_ref` pointing to "stack-allocated" objects are considered to be erroneous.

- Following existing implementation of `check-stack-allocated` rule, it can consider some classes as "stack-allocated" even if there is no explicit `STACK_ALLOCATED()` annotation. See `StackAllocatedChecker.h` for details.

- Separate `class StackAllocatedPredicate` from `class StackAllocatedChecker`.

- This will enable us to use the predicate alone for this rule.

- Modify `check-raw-ptr-fields` and `check-raw-ref-fields` rules to supreess errors for raw pointers/references to "stack-allocated" objects.

- This change is effective only if `check-raw-ptr-to-stack-allocated` is specified.

- Modify `rewrite_raw_ptr_fields` tool to follow this change

- Add `--exclude_stack_allocated` option to exclude raw pointers/references to "stack-allocated" objects from rewriting.



Fixed: 1430659

Change-Id: I423dc68469557ea5f557794270e92767ffcbfa5e

entry.title: Reland: "Recreate inkdrop ripple and highlight when theme changed"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit 2e4bd03ddff02bdfb5202fc50b5e00510e1d82bc



The call to GetInkDrop() will lazily create the ink drop when called. We

need to call HasInkDrop() before GetInkDrop() to avoid create them.



Original change's description:

> Recreate inkdrop ripple and highlight when theme changed

>

> If the theme changed while inkdrop highlight is showing, the ink drop

> highlight will not changed to the right color.

>

> This CL is recreating the ripple and highlight if we observed a theme

> change.

entry.title: gif rendering: Add FilePreviewFactory
entry.content:
The final major piece of the gif rendering model, `FilePreviewFactory`

provides an ergonmic interface to create a `ui::ImageModel` that

contains a visual representation of a file. It manages the lifetime of

those models, so that the caller can be certain that if any copy of the

original model is still active, its controller is also available, but

the controller does not outlive the model.

entry.title: Deflake NetworkServiceBrowserTest.WebUIBindingsNoHttp
entry.content:
The test NetworkServiceBrowserTest.WebUIBindingsNoHttp is flaky. This is

probably caused by the render process occasionally managing to return a

failed result to the browser process before it is killed.



Modify the test to also accept a failed result as success. The test also

verifies that the process is killed, so no robustness has been lost.



BUG=1437440

entry.title: [text-wrap-pretty] Move `ClearNeedsLayout` to `CreateLine`
entry.content:
Before this patch, `NGLineBreaker` calls `ClearNeedsLayout`

for empty text and fully collapsed text. It was originally in

`CollectInlines()`, crrev.com/c/1571113 moved it to

`NGLineBreaker`, but `NGLineBreaker` can be used for

computational purposes and that it shouldn't make such side

effects to the tree.



This patch moves `ClearNeedsLayout` to `CreateLine`. To do

this, empty and fully collapsed text items are appended to

`NGLineInfo` as "empty text items". They are ignored for the

layout purpose, but `CreateLine` calls `ClearNeedsLayout` for

them.



The empty text items are also needed for other use cases,

such as `text-wrap: pretty`.



This patch should have no behavior changes.



Bug: 1432798

Change-Id: Iebea8643ab4f0b59aca8557b5c984b30ac9978d9

window targeters installed out of order by the combination of tuck

browser test.

entry.title: [css-flex] Disable fixed-table's infinite size for intrinsic flex sizing
entry.content:
A fixed-table's intrinsic max-content is ~infinite when it has a

%-width. That's been around for a while and ships in all browsers.



But it is problematic for the new flex intrinsic sizing algorithm

because now the infinity percolates up to the flex container's

min-content size[1]. We obviously don't want a min-content size of

infinity and gmail relies on the old behavior.



So this is a hacky patch that makes fixed-tables max-content size be the

same as auto-tables when an ancestor flex table is calculating its

intrinsic sizes. It will probably be web compatible, but unsure.



This affects both the min and max intrinsic size of the flex container.



[1] New flex min-content algorithm accounts for item's flex base sizes.

A %-width fixed-table's flex base size is its max-content size, which,

as mentioned above, is ~infinity.



Change-Id: I7010fa73df8e88a4812b23780e5d58a3f63da730

Bug: 240765

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4420422

entry.title: Shared Storage: Migrate database to store keys/values as BLOBs
entry.content:
The new Shared Storage API (https://github.com/WICG/shared-storage)

needs to be able to preserve potentially invalid UTF-16 strings that

API users store in the database, so that when they are retrieved, the

same strings are returned.



In this CL, we migrate `SharedStorageDatabase` to use the new `sql::Statement` helpers for storing UTF-16 strings as `BLOB`'s added in https://crrev.com/c/4462153. This approach to preserving potentially invalid UTF-16 strings replaces the initial approach planned in https://crrev.com/c/4413437, now abandoned.



Bug: 1430513,1218540

entry.title: Revert "Migrate from IPP media/media-supported to media-col/media-col-database"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 7635617eba05bf8b9d556d482b23ea0040b270a8.



Reason for revert: Causing failures in All/SystemAccessProcessPrintBrowserTest.UpdatePrintSettings/* on Mac:



https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/Mac10.14%20Tests/33647/overview

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/Mac12%20Tests/8832/overview



Original change's description:

> Migrate from IPP media/media-supported to media-col/media-col-database

>

> Effects of getting the supported paper sizes from CUPS using

> media-col-database instead of media-supported:

> * We get paper sizes as actual dimensions in PWG units instead of having

> to parse them from strings.

> * The vendor ID for each paper size is now determined from its

> dimensions instead of the other way around.

> * Paper display names are now based solely on dimensions, so we can end

> the long game of whack-a-mole trying to get non-standard and duplicate

> paper sizes to display and sort properly.

> * When de-duplicating sizes with borderless variants, we now determine

> whether a size is borderless using its actual margins instead of

> vendor ID heuristics.

> * Dimensions are now formatted properly for the current locale when

> generating display names for unregistered sizes.

> * The algorithm used to determine whether an unregistered size is inches

> or millimeters is better than the one used in CUPS, accounting for

> eighths and tenths of an inch. For example, the size that used to

> display as "200.03 x 148.17 mm" is now properly rendered as

> "7.875 x 5.833 in".

>

> Effects of sending the paper size for a print job using media-col

> instead of media:

> * We now send the "media-source" (input tray) as part of media-col, in

> accordance with IPP standards. Before, we had to use the standalone

> "media-source" attribute, which was a non-standard extension

> implemented in the ChromeOS fork of CUPS.

> * Sending media-col opens the way for work to begin in earnest on media

> type support and borderless printing.

> * We no longer use libcups' janky cupsDestMedia* functions for anything.

>

> Bug: b:199547118

> Test: do print jobs and verify the size, source, and margins are correct

> Test: check the paper size list in the UI for various printers

> Change-Id: I9030283ae22d1f71b20f0237e664af4943fc58c4

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4257505

> Reviewed-by: Lei Zhang

> Commit-Queue: Bryan Cain

> Reviewed-by: Benjamin Gordon

> Code-Coverage: Findit

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1135611}



Bug: b:199547118

Change-Id: I2e3f715f17eee8740797f91f0735d02d6a27084f

entry.title: Avoid dangling ptr warnings in DelegatedInkTest
entry.content:
The DelegatedInkPointPixelTestHelper::SetRendererAndCreateInkRenderer()

method sets resources post-construction, which is a strong hint that

said resource won't outlive the DelegatedInkPointPixelTestHelper

(otherwise we'd likely pass it to the constructor directly). So add

a corresponding method to unset the resource prior to superclass

teardown destroying the resource.

entry.title: CrOS EmojiPicker: Stop passing fuse.basic.esm.min.js to ts_library().
entry.content:
This allows removing an exception in validate_tsconfig.py that was

allowing EmojiPicker to use the allowJs TS compiler flag.



This was unnecessary since EmojiPicker has already been migrated to

TypeScript and only fuse.basic.esm.min.js was requiring that exception.



Moreover, fuse.basic.esm.min.js is an already minified JS file with

corresponding fuse.d.ts TS definition file, and passing it through the

TS compiler is unnecessary and causes extra work during the build.

entry.title: Improve the loop detection for popovers
entry.content:
See [1] for much more context, but the prior CL [2] did not completely

solve the problem. This CL adds a bit to PopoverData that keeps track

of whether we're currently showing or hiding a popover. If that bit

is already true on a subsequent call, it means we have a loop, and in

that case events are disabled and a console warning is generated. In

addition, the loop added in [2] is moved into HideAllPopoversUntil(),

so that it functions for both show and hide.



The test is enhanced to make sure the behavior is interoperable.



[1] https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/9197

[2] https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4472129



Bug: 1307772

Change-Id: I7c9efb8eea3e5dea04c7998e200f0e9e458ef966

entry.title: Revert "[Fuchsia] Set daemon.autostart=false"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 92b247abe4d2219f4b11de089f6fd5aca94c63e3.



Reason for revert: May be the reason for breaking the hardware fleet



Original change's description:

> [Fuchsia] Set daemon.autostart=false

>

> This change controls the lifespan of the ffx daemon by explicitly

> calling stop at the beginning of the test, restart it with the correct

> configurations and stop at the end of the test.

> So that the daemon.autostart can be set to false and any unexpected

> behaviors of bringing up the daemon will be blocked.

>

> Meanwhile, it adds a start_ffx_daemon and stop_ffx_daemon to detect the

> state of the daemon after starting or stopping it. Ideally the

> _run_repair_command can be removed, but I won't go too far in this CL

> and it will be handled later.

>

> Two bugs have been added into the comments so that after both of them

> being fixed within fuchsia-sdk, we can also remove the daemon status

> check from our side.

>

> Bug: fuchsia:92296, fuchsia:125873

> Change-Id: Ifae8d76642f450c47f8d2e53ea3869d70e7f7c53

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4449826

> Reviewed-by: Rohan Pavone

> Commit-Queue: Zijie He

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1135601}



Bug: fuchsia:92296, fuchsia:125873

entry.title: Misc. cleanup.
entry.content:
* Minimize future diffs for landing a CL that adds custom matchers for

`expected` values/errors.

* Shorten code.

* Propagate errors such that tests can avoid crashing when API calls

fail.

* Add some missing #includes.

* Avoid "double negative" conditional ordering.

* Checking the value() or error() of an `expected` must ASSERT whether

it has_value() first, or the test can crash.

* Fix style violations.

* Use `expected` monadic ops.

entry.title: Change Some Spelling Metrics to only be emitted for regular profiles
entry.content:
Change the metrics that relate to per-profile settings, e.g., whether spelling is enabled and what language it is enabled for. Otherwise it's misleading to include the state of spelling in other profiles such as guest profiles when users can't actually modify any spelling settings for those profiles.



Precisely,

- migrate:

SpellCheck.SpellingService.Enabled -> SpellCheck.SpellingService.Enabled2

SpellCheck.Enabled -> SpellCheck.Enabled2

Spellcheck.Windows.ChromeLocalesSupport.* -> Spellcheck.Windows.ChromeLocalesSupport2.*

Spellcheck.Windows.SpellcheckLocalesSupport.* -> Spellcheck.Windows.SpellcheckLocalesSupport2.*

(including marking the old ones as obsolete)

- remove long-expired SpellCheck.CustomWords histogram, as it's not worth the investment in time to revive and migrate to the regular-profile-only version. This histograms.xml cleanup is in http://cr/523178712

- remove the code to emit SpellCheck.DictionaryCorrupted, which is never called. This histograms.xml cleanup is in http://cr/523178712

entry.title: media/gpu/v4l2/test: Rework H.264 frame processing logic
entry.content:
The H.264 decoder had previously overcomplicated its frame processing

logic by holding on to the previous slice data. Additionally the logic

was incorrectly setup as it would not buffer any H.264 pictures and

would set them as ready right away.



This update reworks the frame processing loop logic for the H.264

decoder. The ProcessNextFrame() function is now simplified to perform

only the steps from the start of a frame to the end of a frame. The

function starts by sending the device control structs representing the

start of the new frame. It will then proceed to process any incoming

slices it sees until it reaches the start of the next frame. It will

conclude by finishing any picture processing on the current frame.



Finally, instead of outputting every picture every frame, this update

utilizes the parsed data from the SPS and buffers when pictures are

ready. As there can be multiple pictures marked as ready per call to

ProcessNextFrame(), a queue object is created to indicate whether a

picture is ready or not. This object is subsequently used in determining

when the decoding has finished and reached the end of stream.



This update results in additional bitstreams being able to be decoded

properly. Not all bitstreams from h264_baseline and h264_main are able

to be decoded properly however. This is due to another issue which will

be addressed in a follow up CL.



BUG=b:234752983

TEST=v4l2_stateless_decoder --video=BA1_Sony_D.h264 --md5=checksums.log

TEST=v4l2_stateless_decoder --video=CVSE2_Sony_B.h264 --md5=checksums.log



Change-Id: I7231f2e7df7a0481e3f9f2b8ff4a2ddd4b1bb59d

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4425830

entry.title: Delay starting the loading UI for navigateEvent.intercept()
entry.content:
In a common use case of the navigateEvent.intercept() (the case

where no optional `handler` is provided), we pulse the the loading UI

for very brief period of time. If several navigations happen in rapid

succession (say, a website that updates the url on every keystroke),

this makes the loading UI extremely jittery (in Chrome desktop, we rapidly swap back and forth between the loading spinner and the

favicon).



Instead of immediately starting the loading UI, start a 50ms timer,

and if the navigation remains in progress long enough that the timer

fires, then start showing the loading UI. Jittering is still possible,

but much less likely since it will now avoid the modal case.



https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4408275

introduce a way to "upgrade" an in-progress same-document navigation

that isn't currently showing loading UI to start showing it.

RenderFrameHostImpl::StartLoadingForAsyncNavigationApiCommit() uses

this new capability.



This also fixes long-standing issue the navigation API's loading UI

integration: we had no way to change a browser-initiated same-document

navigation to start showing loading UI. This CL fixes that case

incidentally.



Bug: 1241202

entry.title: OOP-VD: Re-use SharedImages.
entry.content:
This CL makes the OOPVideoDecoder cache the incoming GpuMemoryBuffer

frames received from the out-of-process decoder so that we can re-use

the SharedImages created from them.



Before this CL, every frame received was considered a new

GpuMemoryBuffer. This caused the MailboxVideoFrameConverter to create a

new SharedImage for every such frame and destroy it every time the

frame was released by the client. To avoid this churn, this CL makes the

OOPVideoDecoder behave a bit like a pool (e.g., the

PlatformVideoFramePool): it stores the incoming frames until a

resolution change (or similar event) and re-uses them as needed.



In order to find out if we can re-use a previously received buffer, we

use the GpuMemoryBufferId of the incoming buffers. Note that we cannot

blindly trusts these IDs because it's possible for the remote decoder to

be compromised. That's fine because the logic in this CL should

guarantee that the worst-case scenario is a wrong visual output and not

a security problem.



Performance-wise, I tested this CL with

webrtc.RTCPeerConnectionPerf.vp8_hw_multi_vp9_3x3_oopvd on a nocturne

running it 3 times before and after this CL. I got the following

improvements:



Average system power consumption: 6.10W -> 6.01W

Avg pkg power usage: 2.39W -> 2.35W

CPU usage: 44.93% -> 40.68%

rc6: 49.95% -> 50.51%



Bug: b:277832201, b:195769334

Test: video.*oopvd* on nocturne

Change-Id: Ie9780f9b809e096f2d2aca30f4cee0af3da9c967

entry.title: Reland "[Extensions] Add component extensions to DevTools blocking policy"
entry.content:
This is a reland of https://crrev.com/c/4412168 and

https://crrev.com/c/4437309



This CL adjusts the logic behind the DeveloperToolsAvailability Chrome

policy that disallows DevTools for force installed extensions to also

include component extensions. There is also a carve out to not block it

for two extensions: the Tast test API extension and the virtual

keyboard extension, which are required in the ChromeOS Tast test

environments to be installed as a component extension when they're

running for guest-profiles. See b/278782724 for more details.



This CL also adds tests around the new behavior and updates names to

better reflect the new behavior.



Original change's description:

> [Extensions] Add component extensions to DevTools blocking policy

>

> This CL adjusts the logic behind the DeveloperToolsAvailability Chrome

> policy that disallows DevTools for force installed extensions to also

> include component extensions which use the management permission. See:

> https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/?policy=DeveloperToolsAvailability

> and the associated bug for further details.

>

> Also adds a test case for this.

entry.title: Migrate from IPP media/media-supported to media-col/media-col-database
entry.content:
Effects of getting the supported paper sizes from CUPS using

media-col-database instead of media-supported:

* We get paper sizes as actual dimensions in PWG units instead of having

to parse them from strings.

* The vendor ID for each paper size is now determined from its

dimensions instead of the other way around.

* Paper display names are now based solely on dimensions, so we can end

the long game of whack-a-mole trying to get non-standard and duplicate

paper sizes to display and sort properly.

* When de-duplicating sizes with borderless variants, we now determine

whether a size is borderless using its actual margins instead of

vendor ID heuristics.

* Dimensions are now formatted properly for the current locale when

generating display names for unregistered sizes.

* The algorithm used to determine whether an unregistered size is inches

or millimeters is better than the one used in CUPS, accounting for

eighths and tenths of an inch. For example, the size that used to

display as "200.03 x 148.17 mm" is now properly rendered as

"7.875 x 5.833 in".



Effects of sending the paper size for a print job using media-col

instead of media:

* We now send the "media-source" (input tray) as part of media-col, in

accordance with IPP standards. Before, we had to use the standalone

"media-source" attribute, which was a non-standard extension

implemented in the ChromeOS fork of CUPS.

* Sending media-col opens the way for work to begin in earnest on media

type support and borderless printing.

* We no longer use libcups' janky cupsDestMedia* functions for anything.



Bug: b:199547118

Test: do print jobs and verify the size, source, and margins are correct

Test: check the paper size list in the UI for various printers

Change-Id: I9030283ae22d1f71b20f0237e664af4943fc58c4

entry.title: Revert "Reland: ax: ensure invisible views are not included in platform a11y views tree"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 55e76a938076cb27e453776dee5badc586fad930.



Reason for revert: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1439687#c2



Original change's description:

> Reland: ax: ensure invisible views are not included in platform a11y views tree

>

> Original change

> https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4458529

>

> Revert

> https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4472787

>

> The issue was that `child` (of type id) was sent the

> `isIncludedInPlatformTree` message which is only defined for

> AXplatformNodeDelegateCocoa (and subclasses like

> BrowserAccessibilityCocoa).

>

> Unfortunately, a gfx::nativeViewAccessible could be anything and the

> only real guarantee is that it conforms to the NSAccessibility protocol.

>

> Thus, use AXPlatformNodeDelegate to identify invisible or ignored views.

>

> `accessibilityChildren` sent to the native view accessible should be

> safe since it's part of NSAccessibility.

>

> Fixed: 1439687

entry.title: Fix omnibox test for Lacros.
entry.content:
OmniboxPopupViewViewsTest.ClickOmnibox failed on Lacros. It works by

setting up an omnibox selection and sending a click, expecting that a

handled click will clear the selection.



The problem is that if the omnibox doesn't have focus, the click will

automatically select all text which will confuse the test. To avoid the

automatic select all and remove the dependency on platform docus

handling, this instead sends a drag event to the omnibox.



I believe this is likely to fix Mac where it is disabled, but will

check in a followup.

entry.title: video-conference:add tooltips to tab sliders
entry.content:
TabSliderButton's take a label and tooltip text.

The tooltip text is optional. If it's empty, use the label as

the tooltip text base.



Because TabSliderButton's have state, append the state to the tooltip

text.



Make it standard across all SliderButtons by implementing this on the

base class.



Also, remove calls to SetAccessibleName to ensure that the views::Button

impl of SetTooltipText also sets a matching accessible name.



Finally, update the focus behavior of the header text that houses

the sliders in the VCControls Bubble, and update the VC Controls string formatting in ash_strings.grd

entry.title: [Fuchsia] Set daemon.autostart=false
entry.content:
This change controls the lifespan of the ffx daemon by explicitly

calling stop at the beginning of the test, restart it with the correct

configurations and stop at the end of the test.

So that the daemon.autostart can be set to false and any unexpected

behaviors of bringing up the daemon will be blocked.



Meanwhile, it adds a start_ffx_daemon and stop_ffx_daemon to detect the

state of the daemon after starting or stopping it. Ideally the

_run_repair_command can be removed, but I won't go too far in this CL

and it will be handled later.



Two bugs have been added into the comments so that after both of them

being fixed within fuchsia-sdk, we can also remove the daemon status

check from our side.



Bug: fuchsia:92296, fuchsia:125873

entry.title: media: Introduce MailboxVFConverter::set_unwrap_frame_cb().
entry.content:
Before this CL, we passed the unwrap-frame callback to the

MailboxVideoFrameConverter at creation time. This CL changes that to

pass it separately by calling set_unwrap_frame_cb(). This is in

preparation for CL:4457504 which allows the OOPVideoDecoder to re-use

frames previously received from the remote decoder. In order to do that,

the OOPVideoDecoder will need to have an UnwrapFrame() method that works

similarly to PlatformVideoFramePool::UnwrapFrame(). If that's the case,

then we can only create the unwrap-frame callback when we have an

instance of OOPVideoDecoder, and that happens in

VideoDecoderPipeline::InitializeTask() long after the

MailboxVideoFrameConverter is created.



Note: I considered passing the unwrap-frame callback in

MailboxVideoFrameConverter::Initialize(), but I decided against this

because in CL:4457504, I set the callback callback multiple times in the

name of safety. I did not want to call

MailboxVideoFrameConverter::Initialize() multiple times because doing so

might the impression that it's fine to change the

MailboxVideoFrameConverter's parent task runner.



Bug: b:277832201, b:195769334

Test: video.*oopvd* on volteer

entry.title: slim: Implement rounded corner
entry.content:
The implementation is not entirely based on cc as cc's implementation

has bugs.



The RRectF (in MaskFilterInfo) is on the SharedQuadState is in target

space. Setting a non-empty rounded corner also clips the subtree to the

layer; this is implemented exactly as if MaskToBounds is set.



There are 2 cases where a new render pass is needed:

* The layer is not axis aligned. For similar reason as clip, RRectF

stores an axis aligned rect. There is no special handling added since

MaskToBounds implementation already creates new pass for this case.

* Parent layer already has a rounded corner. In this case, the child

layer is draw to the new pass with its rounded corner, and the

RenderPassDrawQuad draws with the parent rounded corner.



Observed difference from cc:

* Slim always sets fast rounded corner.

* Slim supports rotating rounded corner. cc appears to just break

rounded corner with rotation.

* No need to create new pass if there is only one (axis-aligned)

rounded corner layer on the path to root. Any number of children of

the that layer can use the same RRectF (in MaskFilterInfo), since it

is target space. There is no need for additional render pass.



Bug: 1399283

Change-Id: I24a31c6424c1108b7da92edf2ec26a8f72d2315b

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4457397

Commit-Queue: Bo Liu

Reviewed-by: Kyle Charbonneau

Code-Coverage: Findit

entry.title: Extensions: Don't pass INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE to NativeHost App
entry.content:
Chrome 113 on Windows began directly invoking Native Host applications

rather than using cmd.exe as a proxy. Whenever Chrome is started without

redirecting STD_ERROR, the original CL would pass INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE

as the value of |hStdError|, whereas prior to that CL, the cmd.exe used

as a proxy would launch the process with 0 as the value.



This behavioral difference resulted in application compatibility

problems with host applications that can accommodate a handle of 0 but

which fail when receiving INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE.



This change updates Chrome to always pass along its own |hStdError|

handle, even if it is 0.



Bug: 1433711

Change-Id: I449fe5a4fbacf38de6a59efc4e020122b9f77af0

entry.title: Add PST issuance permissions policy
entry.content:
Add permissions policy for Private State Tokens issuance operation.

Update existing unit/browser tests. Add new unit/browser tests. Add

external WPT tests.



Permission Policy behavior:



1. If there are no permission policy response from server. PST

issuance can be enabled in iframes for same and cross origins

using allow attribute. See

private-state-token-issue-allowed-by-permissions-policy-attribute.tentative.https.sub.html



2. Issuance can be disabled via the new permission policy, see

private-state-token-issue-disabled-by-permissions-policy.tentative.https.sub.html and relevant header file.



3. Permissions-Policy: private-state-token-issuance=* enables

issuance. Cross origin iframes need allow attribute. See

permissions-policy/private-state-token-issue-enabled-by-permissions-policy.tentative.https.sub.html and relevant header file.





Fixed: 1434086

Change-Id: I02c41b45fab9415c135e74eb51d9033c308e7622

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4436709

Reviewed-by: Daniel Cheng

Commit-Queue: Aykut Bulut

Code-Coverage: Findit

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1135556}

entry.title: VC UI: Add unit test for background blur metrics collection
entry.content:
In order to do this, we need to add some getters in some views to access

and click the tab slider.



Note that we can use BubbleViewID::kSetValueButtonMin to access the

views. However, this method is error-prone to future changes (and it is

also broken at the moment), so getting the views straight from the

direct parent in this case is the best approach.



Fixed: b:274506848

Change-Id: Ibf3205bbfb032d31fdc47f280f56661f5fdfb131

entry.title: Misc. cleanup.
entry.content:
* push_back() -> emplace_back() where applicable.

* Checking the value() or error() of an `expected` must ASSERT whether

it has_value() first, or the test can crash.

* Use `expected` monadic ops.

* Shorten code.
